title: Geometry kernel research
description:
## Objective
Research and define geometry kernel strategy for solid modeling.

## Phase 1: Survey Existing Solutions
- OpenCASCADE Go bindings (search thoroughly - any existing wrappers?)
- Other CAD libraries with Go bindings
- Pure Go alternatives (if any)

## Phase 2: If No Viable Bindings
Define minimal custom kernel:
- B-rep vs CSG representation
- Core primitives: box, cylinder, sphere, extrude 2D→3D
- Boolean operations: union, difference, intersection
- Tolerance handling for boolean operations
- Face/edge identity tracking

## Deliverables
- Survey report of existing solutions with viability assessment
- If using existing: binding/integration approach
- If custom: proposed kernel API (Go interfaces), implementation approach
- Sample code showing how a box with a hole would be modeled

## Key Considerations
- Deterministic output
- Stable face identity (needed for join operations)
- Performance adequate for furniture-scale models (dozens of parts)
- Semantic tagging of faces/edges for joinery operations

title: Design graph architecture research
description:
## Objective
Design the core architecture: design graph, part system, and join semantics.

## Research Areas

### 1. Design Graph
- DAG structure for primitives, transforms, and joins
- Node identity stability (UUIDs? content-addressed?)
- Immutable graph operations
- Node-to-source expression mapping

### 2. Part System
- Named part reference mechanism
- Grain direction representation (X/Y/Z dominant axis?)
- Part metadata (intended dimensions, material)
- Parts that emit multiple solids vs single solids

### 3. Join Semantics
- Butt joint specification (which face of part A joins which face of part B)
- Clearance/tolerance model (per joint or global?)
- Hole drilling operations (how to specify position/orientation)
- Fastener embedding (screws - position, diameter, depth)

## Deliverables
- Design graph schema (Go struct definitions)
- Part naming and reference API
- Join operation specification format
- Example: design graph for a simple box with 2 parts joined
- Validation rules (what constitutes valid vs invalid graph)

## Key Constraints
- No module/import system for MVP
- Stock mapping is advisory only (not required)
- Must support progressive refinement (abstract → concrete)

title: GUI framework research
description:
## Objective
Research and select native GUI framework for Lignin CAD.

## Options to Evaluate
1. **Fyne** (https://fyne.io/) - Higher-level widgets, more mature, stable API
2. **Gio** (https://gioui.org/) - Lower-level, immediate mode, lighter weight

## Deliverables
- Feature comparison matrix (widgets, performance, maturity, platform support)
- Minimal PoC: split-pane layout with bottom code editor, top 3D viewport placeholder
- Embedded editor widget evaluation (can we use a real code editor?)
- Final recommendation with rationale

## Key Requirements
- Native app (not web-based)
- Split pane: bottom half code editor, top half 3D render
- Code editor must have: syntax highlighting, line numbers, basic editing
- Cross-platform: macOS, Linux (Windows nice-to-have)
- Live evaluation loop (rate-limited)

title: Lisp evaluation engine research
description:
## Objective
Research and compare Lisp implementation options for Lignin CAD.

## Options to Evaluate
1. **zygomys** (https://github.com/glycerine/zygomys) - Pure Go, embeddable, production-tested
2. **fe** (https://github.com/rxi/fe) - Minimalist approach, would need port to Go
3. **Custom minimal Lisp** - Build from scratch, optimized for CAD DSL needs

## Deliverables
- Feature comparison matrix (data types, performance, embeddability)
- Minimal PoC for top candidate (parser + evaluator)
- Sample user-facing CAD DSL syntax with each option
- Final recommendation with rationale

## Key Considerations
- No macros required for MVP
- Must support: numbers, strings, lists, functions, variables
- Must be embeddable in Go with bidirectional data exchange
- Evaluation speed matters (live evaluation on every keystroke)
